Literature Review: Photodarkening, photobrightening, and the role of color centers in emerging applications of lanthanide-based upconverting nanomaterials have garnered significant attention in recent years due to their potential in light-harvesting applications, photonics technologies, and biological imaging and sensing experiments. The unique wavelength-converting properties of lanthanide (Ln) ions enable the creation of upconverting nanoparticles (UCNPs) that can harness light energy and convert it into a longer-wavelength emission. This process is facilitated by the presence of local color centers, both intrinsic and controllably induced, within these materials. Research into the origins of color centers in Ln-based materials has revealed that they can arise from various sources, including defects, impurities, and lattice strain. These color centers can significantly influence the photophysics of UCNPs, leading to observed photodarkening and photobrightening mechanisms. Photodarkening refers to the decrease in luminescence intensity over time, while photobrightening is the increase in luminescence intensity following exposure to light. The mechanisms underlying these phenomena are complex and involve the interaction of light with the color centers, leading to the formation of non-radiative recombination pathways. The properties of color centers have been extensively studied in Ln-based materials, including yttrium oxyfluoride (YPO4) and lanthanum oxyfluoride (LFO). These studies have revealed that the color centers in these materials can be controlled through the introduction of defects or impurities, allowing for the tuning of their optical properties. This control over color centers has enabled the development of new functionalities in Ln-doped nanocrystals, including afterglow-based bioimaging and X-ray detection. The use of color centers in Ln-doped nanocrystals has also enabled the development of all-inorganic nanocrystal photoswitching. This technology involves the use of a photoswitchable material that can change its optical properties in response to light, allowing for the creation of fully rewritable optical patterning and memory. The properties of color centers have also been explored in the context of X-ray detection, where they can be used to enhance the sensitivity of X-ray detectors. In addition to these applications, the properties of color centers have also been explored in the context of photon avalanching. Photon avalanching refers to the process by which a single photon can trigger a cascade of subsequent photons, leading to an increase in luminescence intensity. The properties of color centers can be used to control photon avalanching, allowing for the creation of materials with tunable optical properties. In conclusion, the role of color centers in emerging applications of lanthanide-based upconverting nanomaterials is a rapidly evolving field. The properties of color centers have been extensively studied, and their potential in light-harvesting applications, photonics technologies, and biological imaging and sensing experiments has been demonstrated. Further research into the properties of color centers is needed to fully realize their potential in these applications.
